clinical_study.brief_title: Study of the Level of a Protein Which Could Predict the Development of a Fungal Infection in Patients With Acute Leukemia
clinical_study.official_title: Study of the Level of Mannose Binding Lectin (MBL) as a Predictor of the Onset of a Invasive Fungal Infection (IFI) During Chemo-induced Aplasia in Patients With Acute Leukemia (AL)

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to investigate levels of a protein, mannose binding lectin, in patients with acute leukemia who develop or not an invasive fungal infection.

primary_outcome.measure: serum level of Mannose Binding Lectin (MBL) in patients with acute leukemia
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1st day of the period of aplasia

secondary_outcome.measure: Serum levels of MBL during an episode of aplasia for both groups of patients studied
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every day except Saturday and Sunday for roughly 3 weeks

arm_group.arm_group_label: patients who develop a fungal infection

intervention.arm_group_label: patients who develop a fungal infection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria :
- persons who have provided written consent
- Patients with national health insurance cover
- Patients with malignant hemopathy who have been treated with chemotherapy able to induce profound neutropenia (PN < 500 / mm3) lasting more than 10 days.
- Patients with malignant hemopathy who have received an autologous bone marrow graft
- Patients with severe idiopathic medullar aplasia (PN < 500 / mm3) who need to be hospitalized for at least 10 consecutive days (with or without treatment with immunosuppressants)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have received an bone marrow PSC allograft (as such patients have a risk of aspergillosis, which appears in most cases after medullar recovery; they will not be included in the study).
- Patients who have received an autologous PSC graf (as the duration of neutropenia is in most cases less than 10 days).
- Patients whose neutropenia, retrospectively assessed, lasted less than 10 days.
